items.title: Impossible to copy list contents to clipboard
items.body:
To be honest, I haven't a clue whether that is a python-markdown problem or something with the wechange.de implementation. Or something completely different. Gut if it isn't your turf, may be you can guide me to the correct contact?

**Problem** als been also reported [here](https://suniversum.de/project/aufbau-digitale-vernetzung/todo/in-veranstaltungen-koennen-in-listen-textpa/)

### Steps how to reproduce:

1. [visit this event](https://suniversum.de/project/weststadt-aktivkasse-bs/event/orga-video-telefonkonferenz/)  
2. Double click string "Vorbereitung"  
    » Expected: String becomes highlighted  
    » Actual: Nothing   😥  

So it will be impossible to copy interesting contents (email address, telephone number, date, whatever else)  from lists in events.

### Additional information
a) It's not a general problem, works fine in postings of other type like [here](https://suniversum.de/project/weststadt-aktivkasse-bs/note/foerderprojekts-zusammenarbeits-besprechung-2/).

items.title: Filter bypass leading to XSS
items.body:
Here is the a PoC for latest version (2.3.8) ``` >>> import markdown2 >>> markdown2.markdown('alert(1);/\*](http://g)->a>alert(1);/*](http://g)->a>', safe_mode=True) '

alert(1);/*->a>

\n' >>> ``` And via safe_mode='escape' ``` >>> import markdown2 >>> markdown2.markdown('alert(1);/\*](http://g)->a>alert(1);/*](http://g)->a>', safe_mode='escape') '

alert(1);/*->a>

\n' >>> ```

items.title: Pygment 2.5.1 is breaking test cases
items.body:
Pygments updated to 2.5.1 early on the 26th. This is breaking some of the unit tests.

I'll make a PR to fix it soon.

items.title: consecutive blockquotes shouldn't be merged
items.body:
It seems consecutive quotes (separated by two line feeds) are merged if there isn't any other text in between. e.g.: ```python from markdown2 import markdown print(markdown('> quote 1\n\n> quote 2')) ``` outputs: ```xml

quote 1

quote 2

``` expected something like: ```xml

quote 1

quote 2

``` Adding non-quoted text in-between results in separate blockquotes as expected: ```python print(markdown('> quote 1\n\nno quote\n> quote 2')) ``` ```xml

quote 1

no quote

quote 2

``` Replacing `no quote` in the above code with a whitespace removes that separation again. The same seems to be true for `python-Markdown`. In GitHub renders markdown as expected: > quote 1 > quote 2

from markdown2 import Markdown

```

items.title: possible regression with 2.3.6
items.body:
Hi

I just was trying to upgrade from 2.3.5 to 2.3.6 and had to back off, because I ran into this:

        html = markdown_module.markdown(
            markdown, extras=['markdown-in-html', 'toc', 'header-ids'])

which triggers this:

```
  File "/Users/tparment/git/r2lab.inria.fr/md/views.py", line 562, in markdown_page
    markdown, extras=['markdown-in-html', 'toc', 'header-ids'])
  File "/Users/tparment/git/r2lab.inria.fr/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/markdown2.py", line 193, in markdown
    use_file_vars=use_file_vars, cli=cli).convert(text)
  File "/Users/tparment/git/r2lab.inria.fr/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/markdown2.py", line 379, in convert
    text = self._run_block_gamut(text)
  File "/Users/tparment/git/r2lab.inria.fr/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/markdown2.py", line 941, in _run_block_gamut
    text = self._do_headers(text)
  File "/Users/tparment/git/r2lab.inria.fr/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/markdown2.py", line 1585, in _do_headers
    return self._h_re.sub(self._h_sub, text)
  File "/Users/tparment/git/r2lab.inria.fr/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/markdown2.py", line 1565, in _h_sub
    self._toc_add_entry(n, header_id, html)
  File "/Users/tparment/git/r2lab.inria.fr/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/markdown2.py", line 1520, in _toc_add_entry
    if level > self._toc_depth:
AttributeError: 'Markdown' object has no attribute '_toc_depth'
```

everything was going fine with 2.3.5

in this particular instance, the input markdown **does not** contain any `[TOC]` flag, this is because the same code applies to several pages regardless of their having a toc or not.

A very quick reading of the code suggests that this _toc_depth attribute is not always set

items.title: Possible XSS in safe_mode using incomplete tags
items.body:
PoC with latest version: ``` >>> from markdown2 import markdown as mark >>> mark('', safe_mode=True) u'

[HTML_REMOVED]

\n' >>> mark('\n' ``` using `safe_mode="escape"`: ``` >>> mark('', safe_mode="escape") u'

<img src="" onerror=alert(/XSS/)>

\n' >>> mark('\n' ``` It will trigger an alert box in Chrome. I think it will be a better approach to encode the incomplete tags as well to prevent it. https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_Filter_Evasion_Cheat_Sheet

items.title: Tests do not pass with current version of Pygments
items.body:
Using Pygments 2.2.0 (the current version at this time), some code block tests fail (apparently because of minor changes to Pygments ouput). They work fine using, e.g., Pygments 2.0.2. Sample diff: ``` --- ./tm-cases/fenced_code_blocks_leading_lang_space.html +++ markdown2 ./tm-cases/fenced_code_blocks_leading_lang_space.text @@ -1,3 +1,3 @@ -
if True:
    -    print "hi"
    +
if True:
    +    print "hi"
     

```

7 tests seem to fail in total, all of them in this category.

items.title: & becomes &amp; in anchor tags
items.body:
The ampersand in `&` is not escaped in normal text, but when used in a hyperlink, it is escaped. ```python >>> from markdown2 import markdown >>> markdown("AT&T") u'

AT&T

\n' >>> >>> markdown("[AT&T](/)") u'

AT&T

\n' ``` Is there a reason for this?

items.title: Search for items only within metadata header
items.body:
When parsing the metadata key-value pairs, it incorrectly searches the entire text instead of the metadata header.
For example, 

```python
content = """---
Foo: bar
---

This is a test:
"""
md = markdown2.Markdown(extras=['metadata'])
md.convert(content)
print(md.metadata)
```

results in  `{'Foo': 'bar', 'test': ''}` while it should return only `{'Foo': 'bar'}`

I have submitted a PR for a fix #260

items.title: Footnote titles not translatable
items.body: The `footnotes` extension generates HTML code like this: ``` ↩ ``` The string "Jump back to footnote %d in the text" is not translatable or customisable. Neither is the U+21A9 character ↩, which isn't ideal in some languages that aren't left-to-right.

items.title: Weird escape for images
items.body:
```python >>> from markdown2 import markdown >>> markdown('![alt text](/path/to/image "title")') '

\n' >>> markdown('![alt text](/path/to/image "title")', safe_mode=True) '

\n' >>> markdown('![alt text](/path/to/image "title")', safe_mode="escape") '

\n' ``` Why does it escape the image path too, is it a feature (the other library doesn't do this)?

items.title: Overgreedy regex in metadata extra
items.body:
In the "metadata" extra, we can introduce metadata by beginning with a fenced key-value block. However, consider the following short sample.markdown document. ``` --- Title: TITLE Etc: ETC --- More can be found at [some site][1]. [1]: http://www.google.com ``` The current regex looks for `key: value` pairs and gobbles them. Here, it also gobbles `[1]: http://www.google.com` and everything in between. That is, using something like python markdown2.py --extras metadata sample.markdown produces only the empty document

I'm currently writing a fix.

items.title: 2.3.2 regression: fully-qualified links are urlencoded
items.body: I think this is caused by GH-230. Sample markdown code: ```markdown [GitHub](https://github.com/lopopolo) ``` Under 2.3.1 with safe_mode = escape renders the following link: ```html GitHub ``` Under 2.3.2 with safe_mode = escape renders the following link: ```html GitHub ```

items.title: Wheel support
items.body:
http://pythonwheels.com/

Right now, only the `tar.gz` file is being distributed on PyPI for [python-markdown2](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-markdown2), which isn't _that much_ of an issue, but it does add some time to installing the package.

This package should be compatible with the Wheel format, considering it doesn't appear to have any C dependencies and it is compatible with both Python 2 and 3. As a result, you should only need to generate a universal wheel and then everyone (on all systems) will get the ability to install python-markdown2 with just the wheel, without having to do any extra work.

items.title: Auto detect URLs and add links
items.body: Something that would be nice is if URLs like ( `https://google.com` ) were automatically rendered as a link like ( https://google.com ).

items.title: how to display line number in a code block?
Metadata: Enable values with multiple lines
items.body:
Currenty, one can only use metadata the following way:

```
key: value
key2: value2
key3: value3
```

This is fine for simple case. However for my static site generator, I would like to have a long summary, which is easier to handle if spread over multiple lines. YAML has support for many ways to declare such values:

```
key: value
key2: |
     long value
     over mutliple lines
key3: >
      or this for example
      is another option
```

I have implemented a solution that monkey patched the class Markdown, and enables the second possibility. I think this would be useful for other people two. You can either still the code directly, or ask for a PR. 
I am sure it's still rough a bit (the REGEX might be better), but we can start from here.

You can find the relevant code here:

https://github.com/oz123/blogit/commit/6b73ee359b856c0a492256812607f41fa1c36eac

I simply override the method `_extract_metadata`.

items.title: Potential Extension
items.body:
I've been using markdown2 a lot in a recent project to convert a \LaTeX document generator into an online research environment.  Combined with MathJax, Markdown2 with the footnotes extension is  pretty much perfect.  However, the one thing that Markdown can't do is number figures and tables.  This is pretty much essential in research papers and is also a useful feature in other styles of documentation.  

Whilst I understand that there are way too many "standards" for Markdown, I wanted to add an extension to handle figure, table and equation numbering to Markdown.  What I've done (in a relatively few lines of code) is add a preprocessor which generates generic "counters" which can be used to number equations.  The syntax is as follows.

When you first want to label an item (figure, table, image whatever), you add a markdown item 

```
     [#counter_id](:item_tag)
```

and when you want to refer to it in the text you use `[:item_tag]`.  Here both `counter_id` and `item_tag` are "words" in the regex sense.

During conversion, the first pass identifies all the labels and creates counters as required and increments them if they're already created.  During the second pass, the counter integers are replaced in the text.  In principle, each counter can have it's own css style associated with it.  At present it doesn't hyperlink the references to the original item but that would be easy to add.

The code is about 40 lines of Python.

So the issue is: Is this more generally useful?  There's almost no support for "exhibit numbering" in any Markdown converters -- which is why I had to write my own.  I could certainly add this as an "extra" in markdown2 if there was general support for it but I don't want to add useless cruft to a project.  Comments?

items.title: "toc" option always appends
items.body:
Currently, the table of contents is always appended to, which causes a problem if the Markdown object is persistent.  For example, the following script will produce HTML for many Markdown files:

``` python
import markdown2
import os.path as path
import argparse

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
parser.add_argument('md_files', type=str, nargs='+', help='Markdown filename(s) to be parsed')
args = parser.parse_args()

markdowner = markdown2.Markdown(extras=["code-friendly", "fenced-code-blocks", "header-ids", "toc"])
html_header = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">

<head>
<meta charset="utf-8">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="./github.css">
</head>

<body>"""

for f in args.md_files:
    with open(f, 'r') as fh:
         html_file = open(path.splitext(path.basename(f))[0] + '.html', 'w')
         html_file.write(html_header)
     html_file.write(markdown2.markdown("## Table of Contents"))
     html_body = markdowner.convert(fh.read())
     html_file.write(html_body.toc_html)
     html_file.write(html_body)
     html_file.write("</body\n</html>")
     html_file.close()
```

If there is more than one file, each file will include the Table of Contents from the previous files with the current file's TOC appended to the end.  This is less than ideal behavior.  The only current alternative is to add in the line `markdowner._toc = None` when done with the current file, but this is supposed to be a "private" variable, so it would be better if there was some method of resetting the table of contents variable.

items.title: Support for CLI css / inline style
items.body:
Would it be possible to add css elements inline or as relative path into the CLI?

For example:

markdown2 -x style https://raw.githubusercontent.com/markdowncss/air/master/index.css readme.md > readme.html

items.title: Code change error
items.body:
Hi, I meet some problem with python code. markdown as follows: `````` ```python @requires_authorization def somefunc(param1='', param2=0): '''A docstring''' if param1 > param2: # interesting print 'Greater' return (param2 - param1 + 1) or None class SomeClass: pass >>> message = '''interpreter ... prompt''' `````` And markdown2 produce: ``````

```python @requires_authorization def somefunc(param1='', param2=0): '''A docstring''' if param1 > param2: # interesting print 'Greater' return (param2 - param1 + 1) or None

class SomeClass: pass

message = '''interpreter ... prompt''' ```

``````

items.title: toc Extra raises TypeError in Python3
items.body:
When `python-markdown2.py` is run with Python3, with the experimental `toc` extra enabled, a `TypeError` is raised:

``` python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./python-markdown2/lib/markdown2.py", line 2458, in <module>
    sys.exit( main(sys.argv) )
  File "./python-markdown2/lib/markdown2.py", line 2443, in main
    html.toc_html.encode(sys.stdout.encoding or "utf-8", 'xmlcharrefreplace'))
TypeError: Can't convert 'bytes' object to str implicitly
```

Despite the exception, the HTML code is generated and is identical to that created with Python2.
### Reproduce

``` bash
$ python2 -c 'import sys; print(sys.version_info)'
sys.version_info(major=2, minor=7, micro=10, releaselevel='final', serial=0)

$ python2 ./python-markdown2/lib/markdown2.py --extras toc index.text > index-python2.html

$ python3 -c 'import sys; print(sys.version_info)'
sys.version_info(major=3, minor=4, micro=3, releaselevel='final', serial=0)

$ python3 ./python-markdown2/lib/markdown2.py --extras toc index.text > index-python3.html
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./python-markdown2/lib/markdown2.py", line 2458, in <module>
    sys.exit( main(sys.argv) )
  File "./python-markdown2/lib/markdown2.py", line 2443, in main
    html.toc_html.encode(sys.stdout.encoding or "utf-8", 'xmlcharrefreplace'))
TypeError: Can't convert 'bytes' object to str implicitly
```

The Markdown text I'm converting is https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/index.text

items.title: The `markdown-in-html` extra has no `optparse` option.
items.body:
There is no way to activate this extra feature when executing from CLI, something like:

```
markdown2 --extras markdown-in-html
```

I noticed this while creating a Wiki page for `markdown-in-html`. I might submit a pull request for this one later during the week.

items.title: Table of contents
items.body: It is so great that a table of contents is implemented, but I can't figure out how to use it. I'm using markdown2 in Django with `context['markdown_text'] = markdown2.markdown(text, extras=["header-ids", "toc"])` but how can I access `toc_html`?

items.title: Disallow javascript: scheme in urls on safe mode
items.body: allowing the javascript: scheme in urls makes the safe mode completely useless in terms of preventing XSS.

items.title: error handling pipe in cell of a 'tables' table
items.body:
E.g.:

```
| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| user | String\|Object | The user UUID or login string or a user object with a `user.dn`, `user.uuid` or `user.login` (i.e. a user object as from `getUser`).user the user record you got from getUser. |
| changes | Object | Changes to the object you want merged in. For example: `{myfield: "blah"}` will add/replace the existing `myfield`. You can delete an existing field by passing in a null value, e.g.: `{addthisfield: "blah", rmthisfield: null}`. |
| callback | Function | callback of the form `function (err, user)`. |
```

Should that escaping work like that?
Likewise the wiki-tables -> tables conversion tool should handle catching that.

items.title: error in parsing lists in special cases
items.body:
original example from dap: https://gist.github.com/davepacheco/ee3b1a72e75508efaf92 My slightly smaller test case: ``` # Section one 1. Test li 1 111111111111111111111111111111111 11111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111 1 # Section two 1. Test li 2 1. subli a 2. subli b 1. Test li 3 ``` And the incorrect generated HTML: ```

Section one

  1. Test li 1

    111111111111111111111111111111111
11111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111
1

Section two

1. Test li 2 1. subli a 2. subli b

  1. Test li 3
``` Expect to get this: ```

Section one

  1. Test li 1

    111111111111111111111111111111111
11111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111
1

Section two

  1. Test li 2

    1. subli a
    2. subli b

  2. Test li 3

``` Interestingly you get the correct behaviour with this input: ``` # Section one 1. Test li 1 111111111111111111111111111111111 11111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111 # Section two 1. Test li 2 1. subli a 2. subli b 1. Test li 3 ``` There is an error in the `pos = end` handling in `_do_lists`. Patch coming.

items.title: Allow html-classes for img
items.body: Please can the `html-classes` extra support `img` tags? Would be very helpful for formatting images when rendered.......

items.title: Horizontal Rule added on a single '*' or '-'
items.body:
A horizontal rule is added if we have only one '_' or '-' by itself on a line, while the [documentation](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#hr) clearly says that we need atleast 3 or more '_' or '-' to create a horizontal rule. The easiest test case is to run the following:

```
import markdown2
markdown2.markdown("*")
```

This returns

> u'<hr />\n'

which should not be the case.

when a list item contains code block, it would affect list below the list. for example: ``` 1. CN 2.0.1-5212 MD5: d8d6012955febd8bdc85a92ce890858c SHA1: 5eb990511d309374625d024db29c11d980eb8dec * test ``` result: ```

  • CN 2.0.1-5212

     MD5: d8d6012955febd8bdc85a92ce890858c
SHA1: 5eb990511d309374625d024db29c11d980eb8dec

    • * test

    ``` the right result should be: 1. CN 2.0.1-5212 ``` MD5: d8d6012955febd8bdc85a92ce890858c SHA1: 5eb990511d309374625d024db29c11d980eb8dec ``` - test

items.title: Don't interpret indented code in fenced code as new block of code.
items.body:
Consider such code:

``` python
def markdown(what, **kwargs):
    try:
        import markdown2
    except ImportError:
        raise CustomError

    md = markdown2.Markdown(safe_mode=kwargs.get('safe_mode', False),
                                                 extras=set(extras))
```

Markdown2 interprets last two lines as separate code snippet and wraps it around with `<code>` again.

![](http://i.imgur.com/2LTfv.png)

This shouldn't happen, right?

Markdown to reproduce this issue:

``````
```python
def markdown(what, **kwargs):
    try:
        import markdown2
    except ImportError:
        raise CustomError

    md = markdown2.Markdown(safe_mode=kwargs.get('safe_mode', False),
                                                   extras=set(extras))
```
``````

EDIT:

``` python
>>> import markdown2
>>> markdown2.__version__
'2.0.0'
```

items.title: Empty lines in fenced code block starts a new code block when using pygments
items.body:
``` python def fine(): # so far so good return 'how is this?' ``` If you are not using pygments, it generates the `
` block correctly:

``` html


def fine():
    # so far so good

    return 'how is this?'


```

And pygments can parse this just fine:

``` python
>>> from pygments import highlight
>>> from pygments.lexers import PythonLexer
>>> from pygments.formatters import HtmlFormatter
>>> 
>>> code = '''def fine():
...     # so far so good
... 
...     return 'how is this?'
... '''
>>> print highlight(code, PythonLexer(), HtmlFormatter())

def fine():
    # so far so good

    return 'how is this?'


```

But running it through Markdown2 inserts an extra `
`:

``` html

def fine():
    # so far so good


<span class="k">return</span> <span class="s">'how is this?'</span>





```

(version 1.4.2)

items.title: extra to generate automatic numbers for headers
items.body:
I'd like to have an extra (I may take a stab at writing it) which generates numbers for headers, for ease of discussion in emails for example. Meaning that an h1,h2,h3,h3 sequence would generate both header ids that are numbers rather than names, but also markup which I could then use to optionally show those numbers (e.g. on hover). I'm thinking of generated code that might look like: ```

first header1

first subheader1.1

first subsubheader1.1.1

second subsubheader1.1.2

``` Maybe it could be an option to the existing header-ids extra.

items.title: fenced code conflicts with code blocks
configure pygments cssclass
items.body:
markdown2 requires this fix to allow cssclass configuration

```
    #old - formatter = HtmlCodeFormatter(cssclass="codehilite", **formatter_opts)       
    formatter_opts.setdefault('cssclass', 'codehilite')
    formatter = HtmlCodeFormatter(**formatter_opts)
```

items.title: Broken in Django 1.4
items.body: This implementation of Markdown breaks in Django 1.4, as per the [release notes](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/releases/1.4/#versions-of-python-markdown-earlier-than-2-1), which is a shame because I prefer this implementation of Markdown for Python.

items.title: add github/stackoverflow-flavored highlighting syntax
items.body:
both github and stackoverflow had great ideas how the language should be specified in markdown:
## stackoverflow

uses two related patterns. this one:

```
    #!language
    blah("blah")
```

is rendered without the shebang line, and uses it only to indicate which language is used. whole shebangs, however:

```
    #!/usr/bin/env language
    blaah("blah")
```

are rendered together with the following code block, as well as giving a language hint.
## github

uses another pattern:

``````
```language
blah("blah")
```
``````
## proposal

instead of creating our own syntax, we should use one that derives from the existing one and renders in other markdown parsers without breaking. `{{{}}}` or `:::` is such made-up sytax.

i think we should support both github’s and stackoverflow’s way, and add this variant:

``````
```#!language
blah("blah")
```
``````

as well as this:

``````
```#!/usr/bin/env language
blah("blah")
```
``````

items.title: bullet points - indentation and spacing
items.body:
I've a demo piece of text that demonstrates 2 problems (and differences) to the original Perl version. It also demos a problem that the perl version also has so that is probably a non-issue.

tested with headrevs as of 2011-07-13.

---

Demo a few different issues with bullet points

NOTE demo 1 is proabably a markdown "feature". The perl (online dingus)
version has the same behavior, i.e. copy.paste this into 
http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/dingus
## 1 odd spacing (possibly caused by p tag?)

Workarounds:
1. this is bullet one, note spacing between this and bullet 2
2. this is bulet two see spacing above and below, they are different
   this is line 2 of bullet two, not sure if this is significant
3. Note there is more spaced between this bullet and the line above
   this is the send line of bullet 3 not sure if it is needed or not.
   
   ```
   /* ---- and now some indented code ---- */
   a = a + 1;
   /* ---- cut here ---- */
   ```

---
## This demos one, maybe two issues - renumbered bullets

intro sentence before bullets
1. Number one bullet
2. This is number two bullet, it is multi line and has some non-numbered 
   bullets. It is possible the bullets below should be indent more but
   I do not think so (note they show up at the wrong indentation level
   in the output)
   - unnumbered bullet 1
   - unnumbered bullet 2
   
   Another paragraph for number 2 bullet.
3. This should be the third bullet point, I think it got confused with the 
   non numbered bullets.
   
   A second paragraph for bullet 3

The end of the text.

http://michelf.com/projects/php-markdown/extra/#table

Also:

I'd thought the google code wiki table syntax was pretty nice, but that page is down for me right now. Also it would problaby be a shame to support tables in markdown2 and NOT have hte same syntax as php-markdown and python-markdown.

items.title: Parsing error with HTML
items.body:
Having an issue parsing text with embedded HTML. The following doesn't convert correctly: ``` ## heading 1 ##
  • item
  • item 2
## heading 2 ##
  • item
  • item 2
``` This results in the following: ```

heading 1

  • item
  • item 2
## heading 2 ##
  • item
  • item 2
``` Notice the second heading didn't get converted. However, if the first list is broken up into separate lines like so: ``` ## heading 1 ##
  • item
  • item 2
## heading 2 ##
  • item
  • item 2
``` then the second heading converts to an `

` as expected. I'm not sure if this is just an issue with lists or html in general where the close tag is on the same line as the opening tag. I'm guessing it has something to do with a greedy regex that is going beyond the first `<\ul>` and matching against the last one. In fact, if the first list is changed to an ordered list `
    `, markdown converts it correctly. Note that the other Python markdown processes all of these cases as expected.

items.title: Python 3 support?
items.body:
I've been a longtime user of python-markdown2 and like the way it just works. I'd like to start using it in a Python 3-based project, but it seems as if there is no goal of porting to Python 3 (I last checked it out a year or so ago -- at that time I did my own port). 

Would you like me to contribute the port I have made, or is there no real motivation to support Python 3 at this time?

items.title: Document whether any “extra” syntax is supported
items.body:
I don’t see anything in your readme about support for “extra” syntax, but the list of test suites implies there are “extra” tests.

You should probably be explicit about this, as it is a major factor people consider when choosing a Markdown library.

items.title: How to create an (video) extra?
items.body:
I'd like one that embeds videos from popular video hosting services upon a simple insertion of a url to the resource.

Or does markdown format provide syntax for video embedding?

Would it make sense support to embed videos? What would be a good way to create an entry in the text?

Thanks.

items.title: No automatic links
items.body: It doesn't seem that markdown2 does automatic links of the form: ``` ``` which should be converted to: ``` www.google.com ``` This is detailed on the Markdown page: http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#autolink

items.title: HTML5 block elements
items.body:
It'd be nice if HTML5 block elements were treated like HTML4 block level elements.  In other words, they should be ignored during Markdown processing.

I've written some code that takes care of this, as an option, but I had to move some regex definitions into a function to postpone the calling of them.  Let me know if you are interested in the patch and I can send a pull request.

items.title: README file name in setup.py
items.body: The README file name in setup.py should probably be changed to 'README.md' from 'README.txt'.  setup.py fails here unless I change that.

items.title: properly escape attribute values
items.body:
It is my understanding that special characters in HTML attribute values must be escaped:

```
from markdown2 import markdown
markdown(u'[foo](http://example.com "lorem [ipsum] dolor <sit> amet")')
```

None of the square or angle brackets in the resulting title attribute are being escaped.

Note that there is a related, but possibly separate issue: When using `link_patterns`, `href`s are not being URL-encoded (e.g. spaces are not encoded as `%20`).

items.title: [shadow] attached text will hang Markdown().convert(contents)
items.body:
_This is a *_shadow issue*\* for [Issue 52 on Google Code](http://code.google.com/p/python-markdown2/issues/detail?id=52) (from which this project was moved).
Added 2011-03-01T23:13:13.000Z by [david.as...@gmail.com](http://code.google.com/u/@VRReQV1YBxhFWwJ9/).
Labels: Type-Defect, Priority-High.
Please make updates to the bug [there](http://code.google.com/p/python-markdown2/issues/detail?id=52).*
# Original description

```
from markdown2 import *
Markdown().convert(open('minimal').read())

seems to hang for a long time.


(it's not actually minimized yet, sorry)
```
